source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Short-term autoclave tests are currently being used by some as a selector for nodular corrosion, a phenomenon which is observed in boiling water reactors.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The present study extends this earlier work on chemical effects to include corrosion performance in ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ steam, one of the predictor tests.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Fifty-three ingots having compositions within as well as outside the specification range for the Zircaloys were melted and fabricated into plate and strip using a conventional fabrication procedure that incorporated an intermediate beta quench followed by working and annealing in the upper alpha region.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The roles of various elements, singly and in combination, on ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ corrosion were examined systematically.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The alloy elements covered the following ranges: tin, 0.02 to $5 . 1 4 ~ \mathrm { w t \% }$ ; iron, 0.04 to $0 . 5 7 \mathrm { w t \% }$ ; chromium, 0.04 to $2 . 7 6 ~ \mathrm { w t \% }$ ; and nickel, 0.003 to $0 . 0 4 6 ~ \mathrm { w t \% }$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: In addition, carbon, silicon, aluminum, and phosphorus were evaluated over the range of standard Zircaloys.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The frequency and severity of nodule formation were generally related to the weight gain for both static and refreshed autoclave tests.
property_name: nodule formation frequency, nodule formation severity, weight gain

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The transition elements chromium, iron, and nickel exhibited the most pronounced effects, with the effect of nickel being dominant.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: High weight gains are generally observed at low concentrations of iron, chromium, and nickel, and low weight gains are observed at high concentrations of these elements.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Heat treatments that affect the distribution of the intermetallics have a significant effect on the corrosion properties of Zircaloy.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Process temperatures in the high alpha-range generally lead to high weight gains for Zircaloy.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: For beta quenching the results depend on the specific conditions of the quench and of the test performed.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Testing in static steam resulted in low weight gains for all beta treatments studied

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: while testing in refreshed steam led to different results depending on quenching rate.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: In the refreshing autoclave tests high weight gains are observed at low quenching rates from the beta.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The best results are obtained by beta quenching at a minimum rate of above ${ \mathfrak { s } } \kappa / { \mathfrak { s } }$
